My "people" were illiterate and their culture - Sicilian Catholicism - was two steps away from the worship of fertility gods. They had never voted, never left Messina, never used indoor plumbing, and had a patriarchal culture in which women worked at home and had 4-10 children and girls were not permitted to attend school.

Back in Sicily, my grandmother - the family story goes - had been yanked from a group of Sicilian kids that had been selected to greet King Victor Emmanuel after announcing that she would ask him why she couldn't attend school with her brothers. In the U.S., she taught herself to read and write English and attended night school to become a citizen. Her culture was not enlightened; it was primitive. Americans worried - as do many of the commenters here re Syrians - that Italians would not assimilate into modern Western society and had values that were incompatible with U.S. democracy.

My Noni's granddaughters and great-granddaughters are teachers, lawyers, a CFO - and so on. I am not underestimating the cultural distance these new refugees have to travel, but neither am I buying the comventional fears about their potential.

My grandparents were refugees. In 1907, a volcanic eruption, earthquake and tidal wave (a classic one-two-three punch) leveled the Sicilian city of Messina. Permitted to enter the United States under a “humanitarian” waiver of immigration laws, my grandfather sailed to New York at age 16, along with his parents, two surviving brothers (a third brother had been killed in the earthquake), his uncle, and the uncle’s family. My grandmother, then age 14, immigrated with family friends, and was soon joined by her sisters and most of the rest of her family.

Italians were not welcome in the U.S. back in those days. People believed that they were lazy, dirty, intellectually inferior and otherwise undesirable. Like most refugees, my family arrived penniless, relying on the help of friends, and the Catholic Church, to find housing and employment.

Today, two Italian-Americans sit on the U.S. Supreme Court and an Italian-American is the governor of New York State. My grandparent’s living descendants number almost 50, all exemplary American citizens, and include my 97 year-old uncle, a WWII veteran who fought in the Battle of the Bulge. In a small steel box in my closet are my grandparents' respective passports — and my grandmother’s hard-won citizenship papers.

Today’s refugee may be the grandparent of tomorrow’s Supreme Court Justice. Every life is worth saving. The U.S. Should work with the EU to rescue the Syrian refugees.

Using the term "bleeding hearts" doesn't really win the argument with me, and I'm still on the fence on this one. It's pretty much a slap in the face to tell people that if they show more compassion than you do that somehow makes them inferior.

If you are going to use a Titanic analogy, you should be consistent. The problem was not too many people in the lifeboats, it was too few lifeboats on the ship. Beyond that, the lifeboats were poorly apportioned, with wealthy passengers loading first, and lifeboats being launched before nearing fullness. Even after the shortcomings, disaster could have been averted had the ship in the area (SS Californian) bothered to investigate why they were firing off signal rockets.

Similarly, in the current refugee debacle, the Europeans were ill-prepared, under-equipped, and some of those in position to help, couldn't be bothered.

While there is a carrying capacity of our planet, we are not there yet, and the war in Syria has pretty much nothing to do with resource depletion. I can imagine the size of the crisis just fine, and I know it can be dealt with by being prepared, equipped, and taking the time to care a little.
